summary: The Department of Energy manages 54 million gallons of nuclear and hazardous waste at its Hanford site in Washington state. DOE has treatment options for some of its low-activity waste: Vitrify it—immobilize it in glass (current plan) Grout it—immobilize it in a concrete-like mixture (potential option) Grouting the waste could save billions of dollars, and several facilities could dispose of it. But DOE faces legal...
title: Nuclear Waste Disposal: Actions Needed to Enable DOE Decision That Could Save Tens of Billions of Dollars
